elements.content: Three new alkaline earth metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), [Mg2(BDC-OH)2­(DMF)3] (Mg-HBDC), [Ca­(BDC-OH)­(DMF)2] (Ca-HBDC), and [Sr­(BDC-OH)­(DMF)] (Sr-HBDC) (BDC-OH = 2-hydroxyterephthalate(2−) anion and DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide), were synthesized by the assembly of BDC-OH and nitrate salts of the metal ions under solvothermal conditions. Single-crystal structure analysis revealed that Ca-HBDC and Sr-HBDC are isostructural to their corresponding MOFs containing 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalalate(2−) anion (H2dhtp) and terephthalate(2−) anion (BDC), respectively. The MOFs were also characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, and powder X-ray diffraction. The obtained MOFs were applied as heterogeneous basic catalysts for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction at room temperature. The catalysts showed good catalytic activity and structural stability in the condensation reaction and could be reused without observable loss of activity.
elements.clean_text: Three new alkaline earth metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), [Mg2(BDC-OH)2(DMF)3] (Mg-HBDC), [Ca(BDC-OH)(DMF)2] (Ca-HBDC), and [Sr(BDC-OH)(DMF)] (Sr-HBDC) (BDC-OH = 2-hydroxyterephthalate(2-) anion and DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide), were synthesized by the assembly of BDC-OH and nitrate salts of the metal ions under solvothermal conditions. Single-crystal structure analysis revealed that Ca-HBDC and Sr-HBDC are isostructural to their corresponding MOFs containing 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalalate(2-) anion (H2dhtp) and terephthalate(2-) anion (BDC), respectively. The MOFs were also characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, and powder X-ray diffraction. The obtained MOFs were applied as heterogeneous basic catalysts for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction at room temperature. The catalysts showed good catalytic activity and structural stability in the condensation reaction and could be reused without observable loss of activity.

elements.content: Metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) were solvothermally synthesized using alkaline earth metal ions and the 2-hydroxyterephthalate(2−) anion (BDC-OH). The MOFs were employed as heterogeneous catalysts for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) were solvothermally synthesized using alkaline earth metal ions and the 2-hydroxyterephthalate(2-) anion (BDC-OH). The MOFs were employed as heterogeneous catalysts for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction at room temperature.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are inorganic–organic hybrid materials constructed from organic linkers and metal ions (or clusters) possessing the advantages of both inorganic and organic components with unique properties. To synthesize MOFs, metal cations such as transition, rare-earth, lanthanide, main group and actinide metals can assemble with organic linkers. Alkaline earth MOFs based on Mg, Ca, Sr, and Ba have been synthesized; however, they have not been extensively studied compared to lanthanide- and transition-metal-based MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are inorganic-organic hybrid materials constructed from organic linkers and metal ions (or clusters) possessing the advantages of both inorganic and organic components with unique properties. To synthesize MOFs, metal cations such as transition, rare-earth, lanthanide, main group and actinide metals can assemble with organic linkers. Alkaline earth MOFs based on Mg, Ca, Sr, and Ba have been synthesized; however, they have not been extensively studied compared to lanthanide- and transition-metal-based MOFs.

elements.content: Unique features of alkaline earth MOFs such as reduced toxicity, low density, stability in air, and fairly low cost make them interesting candidates to be studied. These MOFs have found applications in gas adsorption, catalysis, and luminescence. In the field of catalysis, alkaline earth MOFs were applied as solid bases for “based-catalyzed reactions” including Knoevenagel condensation, aldol condensation, and Michael addition.
elements.clean_text: Unique features of alkaline earth MOFs such as reduced toxicity, low density, stability in air, and fairly low cost make them interesting candidates to be studied. These MOFs have found applications in gas adsorption, catalysis, and luminescence. In the field of catalysis, alkaline earth MOFs were applied as solid bases for "based-catalyzed reactions" including Knoevenagel condensation, aldol condensation, and Michael addition.

elements.content: Knoevenagel condensation between a CO group and an activated methylene group is important in the drug industry and can be catalyzed by zeolites, Lewis acids, organometallic catalysts, and amino-functionalized supports. Some of these materials involve using hazardous solvents and suffer from some limitations such as lack of reusability and high catalyst loading. Many research groups have been working on the development of MOFs as basic catalysts with advantages over conventional inorganic counterparts. In this connection, condensation reactions were carried out to assess the basic properties of some MOFs such as M2(BTC)­(NO3)­(DMF) (M = Ba/Sr, H3BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid), Ba­(pdc)­H2O, and Mg3(pdc)­(OH)3­(H2O)2 (H3pdc = 3,5-pyrazoledicarboxylic acid).
elements.clean_text: Knoevenagel condensation between a CO group and an activated methylene group is important in the drug industry and can be catalyzed by zeolites, Lewis acids, organometallic catalysts, and amino-functionalized supports. Some of these materials involve using hazardous solvents and suffer from some limitations such as lack of reusability and high catalyst loading. Many research groups have been working on the development of MOFs as basic catalysts with advantages over conventional inorganic counterparts. In this connection, condensation reactions were carried out to assess the basic properties of some MOFs such as M2(BTC)(NO3)(DMF) (M = Ba/Sr, H3BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid), Ba(pdc)H2O, and Mg3(pdc)(OH)3(H2O)2 (H3pdc = 3,5-pyrazoledicarboxylic acid).

elements.content: Alkaline earth MOFs exhibited acidic, basic, or acidic–basic sites which can interact with substrates. These MOFs with high and uniform dispersion of metal–oxygen bonds are well-known basic species. Acidic sites in these catalysts can be due to the existence of unsaturated metal centers or potential Lewis acid sites which will be created upon MOF activation. Moreover, polyhedral symmetry distortions in alkaline earth MOFs can facilitate the formation of vacant positions in the coordination sphere and generate Lewis acid sites.
elements.clean_text: Alkaline earth MOFs exhibited acidic, basic, or acidic-basic sites which can interact with substrates. These MOFs with high and uniform dispersion of metal-oxygen bonds are well-known basic species. Acidic sites in these catalysts can be due to the existence of unsaturated metal centers or potential Lewis acid sites which will be created upon MOF activation. Moreover, polyhedral symmetry distortions in alkaline earth MOFs can facilitate the formation of vacant positions in the coordination sphere and generate Lewis acid sites.

elements.content: Here, we have synthesized three MOFs (i.e., M-HBDC (M = Mg, Ca, and Sr)) based on alkaline earth metal ions and the BDC-OH ligand, and additionally we have investigated their catalytic activity for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: Here, we have synthesized three MOFs (i.e., M-HBDC (M = Mg, Ca, and Sr)) based on alkaline earth metal ions and the BDC-OH ligand, and additionally we have investigated their catalytic activity for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction at room temperature.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a PANalytical X’Pert PRO instrument using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded using a Bruker Equinox 55 spectrometer equipped with a single reflection diamond ATR system. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were conducted in N2 atmosphere by means of a Dupont 951 thermogravimetric analyzer. The results of the catalytic tests were analyzed by a gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890A) equipped with a capillary column (HP-1) and a flame ionization detector (FID). Gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (GC-MS) was performed on an Agilent 7890A GC system equipped with an Agilent Technologies 5975C VL MSD with Triple Axis Detector mass spectrometer with an Rtx-5MS column.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Characterization

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a PANalytical X'Pert PRO instrument using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded using a Bruker Equinox 55 spectrometer equipped with a single reflection diamond ATR system. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were conducted in N2 atmosphere by means of a Dupont 951 thermogravimetric analyzer. The results of the catalytic tests were analyzed by a gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890A) equipped with a capillary column (HP-1) and a flame ionization detector (FID). Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) was performed on an Agilent 7890A GC system equipped with an Agilent Technologies 5975C VL MSD with Triple Axis Detector mass spectrometer with an Rtx-5MS column.

elements.content: The BDC-OH ligand was synthesized according to a previous method reported in the literature. To synthesize Mg-HBDC, Mg­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.026 g, 0.101 mmol) and BDC-OH (0.018 g, 0.099 mmol) were added into the mixture of DMF (2.5 mL) and ethanol (1 mL) in a glass vessel. The vessel was sealed, and the mixture was stirred for 30 min followed by keeping it at 90 °C for 20 h. After slow cooling, needle-like crystals of Mg-HBDC were isolated and washed with DMF several times. Elemental analysis found/calcd.: C, 48.03/47.88; H, 4.39/4.50; N, 6.82/6.70.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Mg-HBDC 

The BDC-OH ligand was synthesized according to a previous method reported in the literature. To synthesize Mg-HBDC, Mg(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.026 g, 0.101 mmol) and BDC-OH (0.018 g, 0.099 mmol) were added into the mixture of DMF (2.5 mL) and ethanol (1 mL) in a glass vessel. The vessel was sealed, and the mixture was stirred for 30 min followed by keeping it at 90 °C for 20 h. After slow cooling, needle-like crystals of Mg-HBDC were isolated and washed with DMF several times. Elemental analysis found/calcd.: C, 48.03/47.88; H, 4.39/4.50; N, 6.82/6.70.

elements.content: Ca­(NO3)2·4H2O (0.025 g, 0.106 mmol) and BDC-OH (0.018 g, 0.099 mmol) were added to DMF (2.5 mL) and ethanol (1 mL) in a vessel. The vessel was sealed and the mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature and then kept at 80 °C for 24 h. After slow cooling, plate-like crystals of Ca-HBDC were collected and washed with DMF several times. Elemental analysis found/calcd.: C, 45.63/46.02; H, 4.83/4.69; N, 7.42/7.67.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Ca-HBDC 

Ca(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.025 g, 0.106 mmol) and BDC-OH (0.018 g, 0.099 mmol) were added to DMF (2.5 mL) and ethanol (1 mL) in a vessel. The vessel was sealed and the mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature and then kept at 80 °C for 24 h. After slow cooling, plate-like crystals of Ca-HBDC were collected and washed with DMF several times. Elemental analysis found/calcd.: C, 45.63/46.02; H, 4.83/4.69; N, 7.42/7.67.

elements.content: Needle-like crystals of Sr-BDC were synthesized identical to the procedure mentioned for Mg-HBDC, except that Sr­(NO3)2 (0.026 g, 0.123 mmol) was used instead of Mg­(NO3)2·6H2O, and the reaction temperature was 115 °C. Elemental analysis found/calcd.: C, 38.80/38.76; H, 3.43/3.25; N, 4.20/4.11.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Sr-HBDC 

Needle-like crystals of Sr-BDC were synthesized identical to the procedure mentioned for Mg-HBDC, except that Sr(NO3)2 (0.026 g, 0.123 mmol) was used instead of Mg(NO3)2⋅6H2O, and the reaction temperature was 115 °C. Elemental analysis found/calcd.: C, 38.80/38.76; H, 3.43/3.25; N, 4.20/4.11.

elements.content: To perform the Knoevenagel condensation, 0.06 mmol (based on metal) of the desired MOF was dispersed in solvent (3 mL). Benzaldehyde (1.1 mmol) and ethyl cyanoacetate (0.9 mmol) were added to the suspension. The condensation reaction was performed at room temperature for 1 h while stirring. The solid product was dissolved by the addition of DMF (6 mL) and then analyzed by GC and GC-MS.
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic Activity

To perform the Knoevenagel condensation, 0.06 mmol (based on metal) of the desired MOF was dispersed in solvent (3 mL). Benzaldehyde (1.1 mmol) and ethyl cyanoacetate (0.9 mmol) were added to the suspension. The condensation reaction was performed at room temperature for 1 h while stirring. The solid product was dissolved by the addition of DMF (6 mL) and then analyzed by GC and GC-MS.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for the MOFs were collected on a four-circle κ geometry KUMA KM-4 diffractometer equipped with a two-dimensional area CCD detector using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation. The structures were solved by the direct method using SHELXT and refined using the SHELXL-2014/7 program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. H atoms were treated as riding atoms in geometrically idealized positions with U iso = 1.2U eq of C of aromatic ring or 1.5U eq of C for DMF. The CCDC numbers are 1571177 (Mg-HBDC), 1860716 (Ca-HBDC), and 1571180 (Sr-HBDC). The crystallographic data are summarized in .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Single-Crystal Data Collection and Refinement

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for the MOFs were collected on a four-circle κ geometry KUMA KM-4 diffractometer equipped with a two-dimensional area CCD detector using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation. The structures were solved by the direct method using SHELXT and refined using the SHELXL-2014/7 program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. H atoms were treated as riding atoms in geometrically idealized positions with U iso = 1.2U eq of C of aromatic ring or 1.5U eq of C for DMF. The CCDC numbers are 1571177 (Mg-HBDC), 1860716 (Ca-HBDC), and 1571180 (Sr-HBDC). The crystallographic data are summarized in .

Yang et al. previously reported Mg3(BDC-NH2)3­(DMF)4 and Sr­(BDC-NH2)­(DMF) based on the BDC-NH2 ligand (BDC-NH2 = 2-aminoterephthalate). Inspired by the synthetic process of these MOFs, we made an attempt to isolate the M-HBDC (M = Mg, Ca and Sr) crystals by utilizing BDC-OH instead of BDC-NH2. First, we achieved the isolation of Sr-HBDC at 115 °C by altering the synthesis conditions including ratios of the starting materials and solvents as well as the reaction time and temperature of the solvothermal treatment. Then, almost the same ratios of starting materials and solvents were applied for the isolation of Ca-HBDC and Mg-HBDC. We should note that decreasing reaction temperature made it possible to obtain Ca-HBDC and Mg-HBDC at 80 and 90 °C, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Yang et al. previously reported Mg3(BDC-NH2)3(DMF)4 and Sr(BDC-NH2)(DMF) based on the BDC-NH2 ligand (BDC-NH2 = 2-aminoterephthalate). Inspired by the synthetic process of these MOFs, we made an attempt to isolate the M-HBDC (M = Mg, Ca and Sr) crystals by utilizing BDC-OH instead of BDC-NH2. First, we achieved the isolation of Sr-HBDC at 115 °C by altering the synthesis conditions including ratios of the starting materials and solvents as well as the reaction time and temperature of the solvothermal treatment. Then, almost the same ratios of starting materials and solvents were applied for the isolation of Ca-HBDC and Mg-HBDC. We should note that decreasing reaction temperature made it possible to obtain Ca-HBDC and Mg-HBDC at 80 and 90 °C, respectively.

elements.content: The Mg-HBDC structure crystallizes in orthorhombic with Pbca space group and contains two crystallographically unique magnesium ions. The asymmetric unit of this compound, shown in a, includes two Mg2+, three DMF molecules, and two BDC-OH ligands. In one of the BDC-OH ligands, the hydroxyl group appeared in two positions with the occupation of 0.591(6) and 0.409(6) for O152 and O151 atoms (a), so it has two orientations.
elements.clean_text:
Structure Description of Mg-HBDC 

The Mg-HBDC structure crystallizes in orthorhombic with Pbca space group and contains two crystallographically unique magnesium ions. The asymmetric unit of this compound, shown in a, includes two Mg2+, three DMF molecules, and two BDC-OH ligands. In one of the BDC-OH ligands, the hydroxyl group appeared in two positions with the occupation of 0.591(6) and 0.409(6) for O152 and O151 atoms (a), so it has two orientations.

elements.content: (a) Asymmetric unit and (b) 3-D structure of Mg-HBDC, showing MgO6 octahedra linked by BDC-OH ligands.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Asymmetric unit and (b) 3-D structure of Mg-HBDC, showing MgO6 octahedra linked by BDC-OH ligands.

elements.content: The coordination environment of Mg 1 is filled with one O atom of a DMF molecule (Mg1–O21, 2.116(3) Å) and five O atoms from BDC-OH ligand with the Mg1–O bond lengths from 2.005(3) to 2.229(3) Å. The BDC-OH in the structure of Mg-HBDC displayed two different coordination modes. Two BDC-OH ligands, in which both carboxylate groups have the same coordination fashion, exhibit the η1:η1:μ2-COO– coordination mode and bond to Mg1 through O11 and O14 atoms (a). Two of the ligands around Mg1 adopt the coordination mode and in which the carboxylate groups in each ligand exhibit both η1:η1:μ2-COO– and η1:η2:μ2-COO– coordination modes, and the hydroxyl group is adjacent to the carboxylate with η1:η1:μ2-COO– fashion (b). One of these ligands is coordinated to Mg1 through O4 and O3 (with η1:η2:μ2-COO– fashion), while the other is connected to the metal via its O1 atom (with η1:η1:μ2-COO– mode). The Mg2 center is six-coordinated and binds to two O atoms of two DMF molecules (Mg2–O41, 2.069(3) Å and Mg2–O31, 2.117(3) Å) as well as four O atoms belonging to BDC-OH ligands with Mg2–O bond distances value from 2.041(3) to 2.096(3) Å. Three O atoms around Mg2 (O3, O12 and O13) come from the ligand with η1:η1:μ2-COO– coordination mode. The selected bond lengths and angles are given in Table S1 and are in agreement with the literature. The octahedrons of MgO6 around Mg1 and Mg2 are joined in the corner via O3 and are further interconnected by BDC-OH ligands to generate the 3-D MOF of Mg-HBDC seen in b. To the best of our knowledge, there is only one report, [(CH3)2NH2]­[Mg3(OH)­(BDC-OH)­(TPT)] (TPT = 2,4,6-tri­(4-pyridinyl)-1,3,5-triazine), for magnesium MOF based on BDC-OH; however, magnesium frameworks based on the H4dhtp ligand such as [(CH3)2NH2]­[Mg3(OH)­(H2dhtp)3­(H2O)3], [(CH3)2NH2]­[Mg3(OH)­(H2dhtp)3­(TPT)] and [Mg2(H2dhtp)1.5­(DMAc)4]­Cl­·DMAc were previously reported (H4dhtp = 2,5-dihydroxy-terepthalic acid and DMAc = N,N-dimethylacetamide). The H4dhtp ligand in [Mg2(H2dhtp)1.5­(DMAc)4]­Cl·DMAc displayed coordination modes similar to those observed for the BDC-OH ligand in Mg-HBDC. Unlike this structure, the hydroxyl groups in Mg-HBDC are not coordinated to the metal centers and just involve in hydrogen bonding interactions.

elements.content: Structural analysis of Ca-HBDC exhibits a three-dimensional (3-D) extended structure that crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c. The molecular structure of Ca-HBDC is displayed in a and contains one Ca2+, half of BDC-OH, and one DMF in the asymmetric unit. The 2-hydroxyterephthalate(2−) anion ligand lies in the inversion center, so the hydroxyl group statistically occupied two positions (see a). The metal center is six-coordinated and is connected to four O atoms belonging to four carboxylate groups of BDC-OH ligands with Ca–O bond values from 2.2938(15) to 2.3287(15) Å and two O atoms from DMF molecules (Ca–O, 2.3737(17) Å). The bond lengths for this structure, given in Table S2, lie within the range of those reported previously. Each BDC-OH ligand in this MOF exhibits the η1:η1:μ2-COO– mode for the carboxylate groups (a). The adjacent Ca2+ ions are linked by two bridging BDC-OH with the distance of 4.980 Å and form an eight-membered ring Ca2C2O4 seen in b. The 3-D extended structure shows channels running along the c axis, and the coordinated DMF molecules are arrayed toward the channels (c). The Ca-HBDC is the first example of MOFs based on Ca2+ and the BDC-OH ligand. This structure is isostructural to previously reported [Ca­(H2dhtp)­(DMF)2] (H2dhtp = 2,5- dihydroxyterephthalate anion) containing the functionalized BDC ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Structure Description of Ca-HBDC 

Structural analysis of Ca-HBDC exhibits a three-dimensional (3-D) extended structure that crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c. The molecular structure of Ca-HBDC is displayed in a and contains one Ca2+, half of BDC-OH, and one DMF in the asymmetric unit. The 2-hydroxyterephthalate(2-) anion ligand lies in the inversion center, so the hydroxyl group statistically occupied two positions (see a). The metal center is six-coordinated and is connected to four O atoms belonging to four carboxylate groups of BDC-OH ligands with Ca-O bond values from 2.2938(15) to 2.3287(15) Å and two O atoms from DMF molecules (Ca-O, 2.3737(17) Å). The bond lengths for this structure, given in Table S2, lie within the range of those reported previously. Each BDC-OH ligand in this MOF exhibits the η1:η1:μ2-COO- mode for the carboxylate groups (a). The adjacent Ca2+ ions are linked by two bridging BDC-OH with the distance of 4.980 Å and form an eight-membered ring Ca2C2O4 seen in b. The 3-D extended structure shows channels running along the c axis, and the coordinated DMF molecules are arrayed toward the channels (c). The Ca-HBDC is the first example of MOFs based on Ca2+ and the BDC-OH ligand. This structure is isostructural to previously reported [Ca(H2dhtp)(DMF)2] (H2dhtp = 2,5- dihydroxyterephthalate anion) containing the functionalized BDC ligand.

elements.content: Compound Sr-HBDC crystallizes in trigonal P32 space group. As seen in a, the asymmetric unit of Sr-HBDC contains one Sr2+, one DMF molecule, and one BDC-OH ligand. Each metal center is coordinated to eight O atoms including one O from DMF molecule (O6) and seven O atoms of five BDC-OH anionic ligands to form bicapped octahedrons around the Sr2+ ion. Two carboxylate groups in each BDC-OH displayed different coordination modes (c). The Sr2+ is bound to two O atoms (O3 and O4) from BDC-OH ligands in which the carboxylate groups adopt the η2:η2:μ3-COO– coordination mode. The other two BDC-OH ligands around Sr2+ exhibit carboxylate groups with a η1:η2:μ2-COO– fashion. One of these molecules is coordinated through O1, and the other is connected to Sr2+ via O1 and O2 atoms. The coordination site of the metal ion is completed with two O atoms (O3 and O4) from one BDC-OH ligand containing a carboxylate group with η2:η2:μ3-COO– coordination mode. In the bicapped octahedron, the Sr–O bond lengths ranges from 2.489(6) to 2.742(5) Å, and the shortest Sr–O6 length is from the DMF molecule. The bond lengths and angles presented in Table S3 are in agreement with the those reported in the literature. The cis and trans O–Sr–O angles deviate from the corresponding ideal angles of 90° and 180° in a bicapped octahedron.
elements.clean_text:
Structure Description of Sr-HBDC 

Compound Sr-HBDC crystallizes in trigonal P32 space group. As seen in a, the asymmetric unit of Sr-HBDC contains one Sr2+, one DMF molecule, and one BDC-OH ligand. Each metal center is coordinated to eight O atoms including one O from DMF molecule (O6) and seven O atoms of five BDC-OH anionic ligands to form bicapped octahedrons around the Sr2+ ion. Two carboxylate groups in each BDC-OH displayed different coordination modes (c). The Sr2+ is bound to two O atoms (O3 and O4) from BDC-OH ligands in which the carboxylate groups adopt the η2:η2:μ3-COO- coordination mode. The other two BDC-OH ligands around Sr2+ exhibit carboxylate groups with a η1:η2:μ2-COO- fashion. One of these molecules is coordinated through O1, and the other is connected to Sr2+ via O1 and O2 atoms. The coordination site of the metal ion is completed with two O atoms (O3 and O4) from one BDC-OH ligand containing a carboxylate group with η2:η2:μ3-COO- coordination mode. In the bicapped octahedron, the Sr-O bond lengths ranges from 2.489(6) to 2.742(5) Å, and the shortest Sr-O6 length is from the DMF molecule. The bond lengths and angles presented in Table S3 are in agreement with the those reported in the literature. The cis and trans O-Sr-O angles deviate from the corresponding ideal angles of 90° and 180° in a bicapped octahedron.

elements.content: The adjacent bicapped octahedral are joined together through their faces to form chains along the c axis which are linked via bridging BDC-OH molecules and generate a 3-D network containing triangular channels. Two types of channels exist in this structure; the smaller ones are empty, while the larger ones are occupied with DMF molecules. To the best of our knowledge, Sr-HBDC is the first structure of strontium MOF which is constructed by the BDC-OH ligand. The MOF is isostructural to [Sr­(BDC)­(DMF)] (BDC = terephthalate(2−) ligand) that is formed based on the nonfunctionalized BDC ligand.

PXRD of M-HBDC (M = Mg, Ca, Sr)

The PXRD patterns of the MOFs are illustrated in . The purity of the prepared MOFs can be confirmed by comparing the experimental PXRD patterns to their corresponding simulated patterns. The simulated PXRD spectra of Ca-HBDC and Sr-HBDC are similar to the patterns of [Ca(H2dhtp)(DMF)2] and [Sr(BDC)(DMF)] reported by Liang et al. and Pan et al., respectively (Figure S1). It is observed that the structure and pore shapes of Ca-HBDC are similar to [Ca(H2dhtp)(DMF)2], and the Sr-HBDC is isostructural to [Sr(BDC)(DMF)].

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses of the MOFs were conducted to study the thermal stability of the prepared compounds (). TGA analyses revealed that all three MOFs possess high thermal stability. In the TG curve of Mg-HBDC, the initial weight loss below 140 °C could be ascribed to the removal of surface-adsorbed solvents. The MOF exhibits the first weight loss up to 200 °C with the weight loss of 14%, which could be due to the removal of one coordinated DMF molecule. The removal of the other two DMF ligands occurs at 200–320 °C with a weight loss of 25% (calculated 23.3%), and then the framework collapse begins at 320 °C. The Ca-HBDC and Sr-HBDC show no weight loss up to 150 °C, and then the solvent removal and the framework decomposition occur up to 900 °C. The Ca-HBDC and Sr-HBDC lost 83.9% and 76.6% of their weight at 900 °C, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability of M-HBDC (M = Mg, Ca, Sr)

Thermogravimetric analyses of the MOFs were conducted to study the thermal stability of the prepared compounds (). TGA analyses revealed that all three MOFs possess high thermal stability. In the TG curve of Mg-HBDC, the initial weight loss below 140 °C could be ascribed to the removal of surface-adsorbed solvents. The MOF exhibits the first weight loss up to 200 °C with the weight loss of 14%, which could be due to the removal of one coordinated DMF molecule. The removal of the other two DMF ligands occurs at 200-320 °C with a weight loss of 25% (calculated 23.3%), and then the framework collapse begins at 320 °C. The Ca-HBDC and Sr-HBDC show no weight loss up to 150 °C, and then the solvent removal and the framework decomposition occur up to 900 °C. The Ca-HBDC and Sr-HBDC lost 83.9% and 76.6% of their weight at 900 °C, respectively.

elements.content: To inspect the catalytic activity of the MOFs, they were employed as heterogeneous catalysts for Knoevenagel condensation of benzaldehyde with ethyl cyanoacetate. The condensation reaction was performed at room temperature for 1 h, and the results are summarized in . The formation of the product (ethyl trans-α-cyanocinnamate) was confirmed by GC-MS (Figure S2). It can be seen that all three MOFs showed good catalytic activity in the reaction at room temperature in all solvents. The MOFs displayed more catalytic activity in ethanol rather than dichloromethane and toluene. This can be explained with increasing polarity of the solvents as ethanol> dichloromethane > toluene. Similar results were reported for the production of 4H-pyran derivatives using Mg-based MOF, [Mg3(NDC)3­(DMF)4]·H2O (NDC = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid), as catalyst and ethanol as polar protic solvent.
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic Tests

To inspect the catalytic activity of the MOFs, they were employed as heterogeneous catalysts for Knoevenagel condensation of benzaldehyde with ethyl cyanoacetate. The condensation reaction was performed at room temperature for 1 h, and the results are summarized in . The formation of the product (ethyl trans-α-cyanocinnamate) was confirmed by GC-MS (Figure S2). It can be seen that all three MOFs showed good catalytic activity in the reaction at room temperature in all solvents. The MOFs displayed more catalytic activity in ethanol rather than dichloromethane and toluene. This can be explained with increasing polarity of the solvents as ethanol> dichloromethane > toluene. Similar results were reported for the production of 4H-pyran derivatives using Mg-based MOF, [Mg3(NDC)3(DMF)4]⋅H2O (NDC = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid), as catalyst and ethanol as polar protic solvent.

elements.content: The reusability of the MOFs was also examined in the catalyzed condensation reaction, and the results are given in (entry 10–12). To inspect the reusability, MOFs were applied for the condensation of benzaldehyde with ethyl cyanoacetate using ethanol as solvent. After 1 h, the white solid product was dissolved by the addition of DMF, the catalysts were separated by filtration and washed with DMF and then ethanol several times. The recycled catalysts were reused for the reaction under similar conditions mentioned for the fresh MOFs. The results reveal that the MOF catalysts can be reused for the reaction without a noticeable decrease in their catalytic activity.

The recycled catalysts were reused for the reaction under similar conditions mentioned for the fresh MOFs. The results reveal that the MOF catalysts can be reused for the reaction without a noticeable decrease in their catalytic activity.

elements.content: The FT-IR spectra of the recycled MOFs () correspond to the spectra of the pristine MOF catalysts and displayed the characteristic peaks of the BDC-OH and DMF ligands. In the fresh MOFs, the νas (C–O) vibrations of the BDC-OH ligand appeared at 1650 and 1593 cm–1 (for Mg-HBDC), 1652 and 1585 cm–1 (for Ca-HBDC) as well as 1658 and 1564 cm–1 (for Sr-HBDC). The peak at 1398–1417 cm–1 in the spectra can be attributed to νs (C–O) vibrations of this ligand. For all three MOFs, two peaks are seen around 670 and 960 cm–1, which can be assigned to DMF ligands.

elements.content: Knoevenagel condensation reactions are known to be catalyzed in the presence of acidic, basic, and acid–base bifunctional catalysts. Regarding MOFs containing carboxylate ligands, the M n+-O2– Lewis acid–base can catalyze the Knoevenagel condensation. For instance, the catalytic activity of [Zn­(ADA)­(L)]·2H2O (ADA = 1,3-adamantanediacetic acid and L = 4-pyridylcarboxaldehydeisonicotinoylhydrazone) and [Zn2(oba)4­(3-bpdh)2]·4H2O (oba = 4,4′-oxybis­(benzoic acid) and 3-bpdh = N,N′-bis­(1 pyridine-3-yl-ethylidene)-hydrazine) have been associated with the M n+-O2– Lewis acid–base pair which can catalyze Knoevenagel condensation.
elements.clean_text: Knoevenagel condensation reactions are known to be catalyzed in the presence of acidic, basic, and acid-base bifunctional catalysts. Regarding MOFs containing carboxylate ligands, the M n+-O2- Lewis acid-base can catalyze the Knoevenagel condensation. For instance, the catalytic activity of [Zn(ADA)(L)]⋅2H2O (ADA = 1,3-adamantanediacetic acid and L = 4-pyridylcarboxaldehydeisonicotinoylhydrazone) and [Zn2(oba)4(3-bpdh)2]⋅4H2O (oba = 4,4'-oxybis(benzoic acid) and 3-bpdh = N,N'-bis(1 pyridine-3-yl-ethylidene)-hydrazine) have been associated with the M n+-O2- Lewis acid-base pair which can catalyze Knoevenagel condensation.

elements.content: Concerning M-HBDC (M = Mg, Ca, Sr) MOFs reported here, the polarized M n+–O2– bonds in the structures endow the MOFs with cooperative Lewis acid–base sites which can synergistically catalyze the reaction. On the basis of the reported mechanism for Knoevenagel condensation, the alkaline earth ions impart the acidic sites and interact with the CO group of benzaldehyde which improves the electrophilicity of the carbon of CO group. Also, the basic sites of the MOFs which are associated with the O atoms of BDC-OH can interact with the methylene group of ethyl cyanoacetate and facilitate its reaction with benzaldehyde.

Also, the basic sites of the MOFs which are associated with the O atoms of BDC-OH can interact with the methylene group of ethyl cyanoacetate and facilitate its reaction with benzaldehyde.

elements.content: The catalytic activity of the prepared MOFs for Knoevenagel condensation of benzaldehyde with ethyl cyanoacetate is compared to some reported catalysts (). The M-HBDC MOFs are capable of catalyzing the condensation reaction at room temperature compared to some other MOF catalysts (entries 1 and 2). Also, our MOFs afforded high conversions (above 89%) within shorter reaction time (1 h) at room temperature using ethanol as green solvent, whereas other alkaline earth MOFs in (entries 3 and 4) performed at higher temperatures in the presence of toluene.

We have synthesized three new MOFs (M-HBDC (M = Mg, Ca, Sr)) through solvothermal assembly of alkaline earth metal salts and the BDC-OH ligand. Ca-HBDC and Sr-HBDC structures are the first MOFs reported based on Ca2+ and Sr2+ using the BDC-OH ligand. Ca-HBDC is isostructural to the known [Ca­(H2dhtp)­(DMF)2] constructed by the H2dhtp2– ligand. Sr-HBDC displayed a new topological type and is isostructural to the known [Sr­(BDC)­(DMF)] synthesized using the BDC ligand. The MOFs showed good stability and represented good catalytic activity for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction of benzaldehyde with ethyl cyanoacetate at room temperature under mild conditions. The reported MOFs are able to catalyze the Knoevenagel condensation reaction within a short reaction time in ethanol as a green solvent. Considering the metal ions and their coordination environment, the prepared catalysts could be considered as acid–base catalysts that catalyze the reaction synergistically. The alkaline earth MOFs with excellent dispersion of active catalytic sites and high thermal stability will be attractive in the field of heterogeneous catalysis in terms of sustainability.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have synthesized three new MOFs (M-HBDC (M = Mg, Ca, Sr)) through solvothermal assembly of alkaline earth metal salts and the BDC-OH ligand. Ca-HBDC and Sr-HBDC structures are the first MOFs reported based on Ca2+ and Sr2+ using the BDC-OH ligand. Ca-HBDC is isostructural to the known [Ca(H2dhtp)(DMF)2] constructed by the H2dhtp2- ligand. Sr-HBDC displayed a new topological type and is isostructural to the known [Sr(BDC)(DMF)] synthesized using the BDC ligand. The MOFs showed good stability and represented good catalytic activity for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction of benzaldehyde with ethyl cyanoacetate at room temperature under mild conditions. The reported MOFs are able to catalyze the Knoevenagel condensation reaction within a short reaction time in ethanol as a green solvent. Considering the metal ions and their coordination environment, the prepared catalysts could be considered as acid-base catalysts that catalyze the reaction synergistically. The alkaline earth MOFs with excellent dispersion of active catalytic sites and high thermal stability will be attractive in the field of heterogeneous catalysis in terms of sustainability.

cln_elements.content:
The BDC-OH ligand was synthesized according to a previous method reported in the literature. To synthesize Mg-HBDC, Mg­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.026 g, 0.101 mmol) and BDC-OH (0.018 g, 0.099 mmol) were added into the mixture of DMF (2.5 mL) and ethanol (1 mL) in a glass vessel. The vessel was sealed, and the mixture was stirred for 30 min followed by keeping it at 90 °C for 20 h. After slow cooling, needle-like crystals of Mg-HBDC were isolated and washed with DMF several times. Elemental analysis found/calcd.: C, 48.03/47.88; H, 4.39/4.50; N, 6.82/6.70.

Synthesis of <bold>Ca-HBDC</bold>

Ca­(NO3)2·4H2O (0.025 g, 0.106 mmol) and BDC-OH (0.018 g, 0.099 mmol) were added to DMF (2.5 mL) and ethanol (1 mL) in a vessel. The vessel was sealed and the mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature and then kept at 80 °C for 24 h. After slow cooling, plate-like crystals of Ca-HBDC were collected and washed with DMF several times. Elemental analysis found/calcd.: C, 45.63/46.02; H, 4.83/4.69; N, 7.42/7.67.

Synthesis of <bold>Sr-HBDC</bold>

Needle-like crystals of Sr-BDC were synthesized identical to the procedure mentioned for Mg-HBDC, except that Sr­(NO3)2 (0.026 g, 0.123 mmol) was used instead of Mg­(NO3)2·6H2O, and the reaction temperature was 115 °C. Elemental analysis found/calcd.: C, 38.80/38.76; H, 3.43/3.25; N, 4.20/4.11.

Synthesis of Mg-HBDC 

The BDC-OH ligand was synthesized according to a previous method reported in the literature. To synthesize Mg-HBDC, Mg(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.026 g, 0.101 mmol) and BDC-OH (0.018 g, 0.099 mmol) were added into the mixture of DMF (2.5 mL) and ethanol (1 mL) in a glass vessel. The vessel was sealed, and the mixture was stirred for 30 min followed by keeping it at 90 °C for 20 h. After slow cooling, needle-like crystals of Mg-HBDC were isolated and washed with DMF several times. Elemental analysis found/calcd.: C, 48.03/47.88; H, 4.39/4.50; N, 6.82/6.70.

Synthesis of Ca-HBDC 

Ca(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.025 g, 0.106 mmol) and BDC-OH (0.018 g, 0.099 mmol) were added to DMF (2.5 mL) and ethanol (1 mL) in a vessel. The vessel was sealed and the mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature and then kept at 80 °C for 24 h. After slow cooling, plate-like crystals of Ca-HBDC were collected and washed with DMF several times. Elemental analysis found/calcd.: C, 45.63/46.02; H, 4.83/4.69; N, 7.42/7.67.

Synthesis of Sr-HBDC 

Needle-like crystals of Sr-BDC were synthesized identical to the procedure mentioned for Mg-HBDC, except that Sr(NO3)2 (0.026 g, 0.123 mmol) was used instead of Mg(NO3)2⋅6H2O, and the reaction temperature was 115 °C. Elemental analysis found/calcd.: C, 38.80/38.76; H, 3.43/3.25; N, 4.20/4.11.

cln_elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses of the MOFs were conducted to study the thermal stability of the prepared compounds (). TGA analyses revealed that all three MOFs possess high thermal stability. In the TG curve of Mg-HBDC, the initial weight loss below 140 °C could be ascribed to the removal of surface-adsorbed solvents. The MOF exhibits the first weight loss up to 200 °C with the weight loss of 14%, which could be due to the removal of one coordinated DMF molecule. The removal of the other two DMF ligands occurs at 200–320 °C with a weight loss of 25% (calculated 23.3%), and then the framework collapse begins at 320 °C. The Ca-HBDC and Sr-HBDC show no weight loss up to 150 °C, and then the solvent removal and the framework decomposition occur up to 900 °C. The Ca-HBDC and Sr-HBDC lost 83.9% and 76.6% of their weight at 900 °C, respectively.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability of M-HBDC (M = Mg, Ca, Sr)

Thermogravimetric analyses of the MOFs were conducted to study the thermal stability of the prepared compounds (). TGA analyses revealed that all three MOFs possess high thermal stability. In the TG curve of Mg-HBDC, the initial weight loss below 140 °C could be ascribed to the removal of surface-adsorbed solvents. The MOF exhibits the first weight loss up to 200 °C with the weight loss of 14%, which could be due to the removal of one coordinated DMF molecule. The removal of the other two DMF ligands occurs at 200-320 °C with a weight loss of 25% (calculated 23.3%), and then the framework collapse begins at 320 °C. The Ca-HBDC and Sr-HBDC show no weight loss up to 150 °C, and then the solvent removal and the framework decomposition occur up to 900 °C. The Ca-HBDC and Sr-HBDC lost 83.9% and 76.6% of their weight at 900 °C, respectively.

decomposition temperature.type: removal of one coordinated DMF molecule
removal of the other two DMF ligands

| entry | catalyst | substrates | solvent | temperature (°C) | time (h) | conversion (%) | refs |

| 3     | Mg₂dobdc [dobdc⁴⁻ = 2,5-dioxidoterephthalate] (0.073 g) | benzaldehyde (1 mmol), ethyl cyanoacetate (1 mmol) | toluene (2 mL) | 70 | 24 | 14 | [^43] |
| 4     | Ba₂(BTC)(NO₃) [BTC³⁻ = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate] (0.05 g) | benzaldehyde (1 mmol), ethyl cyanoacetate (1 mmol) | toluene (2 mL) | 110 | 24 | 85 | [^21] |
